speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: Welcome to Open Minds from Creative Commons. I'm Oney-Ann Ucom, CC's Campaigns Manager.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: We're celebrating Creative Commons' 20th anniversary this year, and one of the ways

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: we're doing that is with this podcast, a series of conversations with people working on issues

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: we're involved with and subjects we're excited about.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: We're just 10 days away from the 2021 CC Global Summit taking place virtually from September the

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: 20th to the 24th. We have a robust program for you filled with over 150 sessions, 285 speakers and countless opportunities for networking and making

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: meaningful connections. Join us from wherever you are as we take stock of the latest developments

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: in the open movement, celebrate 20 years of creative commons and explore better sharing

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: and the future of open. You can find the registration link in the episode description.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: To get you as excited as we are for this year's summit, in this episode we'll be taking a short

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: tour around the globe and speaking to three of our keynote speakers. First stop, Nairobi, Kenya,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: where we'll be talking to Angela Odur-Lungati. Angela is the Executive Director of Ushahidi, a global

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: non-profit technology company that builds tools for democratizing information, increasing

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: transparency, and lowering barriers for individuals to raise their voices.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: So my name is Angela Odor-Lungati. I'm a technologist, community builder, and open source software advocate who's very passionate about building and using appropriate technology tools to impact the lives of marginalized groups.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: I am also the ED or Executive Director of Wushahidi, which is a global nonprofit tech company that helps communities to quickly collect and share information that enables them to raise voices,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: inform decisions, and influence change. We build open source tools that have been used in over 160

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: countries in the last 13 years, gathering 50 million reports to advance democracy,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: report incidents, mobilize for crisis response, simplify research, encourage activism, address

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: challenges, influence change,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and improve society. So there's a bunch of different examples that I could share really

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: quickly. For example, the Haiti earthquake in 2010. There's the Nepal earthquake recently,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: also been used for COVID-19 response. So's many many examples of where our tools have been

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: used in the fight for social justice. Amazing thank you so much. Ushahidi does some fantastic

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: work and I'd love if you could tell us the meaning of the word Ushahidi. Yeah so Ushahidi is a Swahili word that means testimony.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: It's, you know, we're actually born out of the post-election violence that broke out in Kenya back in 2007, 2008. So for those who don't know, at that time, our elections were marked by, you know, it was marked by very high tribal tensions.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And so, of course, when results were announced, violence broke out in different parts of the country.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And the mainstream media was unable to report exactly what was happening in those different pockets.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: The government was also trying to tell me how severe the situation was.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And many of us were stuck in our houses, not knowing what was happening. And so what the founders did was then come up with or rather develop a platform that would allow ordinary citizens to send in text messages, emails or tweets and have that visualized on a map, essentially giving them a voice where no one else could or would.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: So that's where the name comes from.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: It was really bearing witness to what was happening to Kenya at that time

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: from the eyes and from people's lived experiences. You've been executive director of Ushahidi since

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: mid-late 2019, I believe, and it's fair to say that the world has changed leaps and bounds since,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: you know, the end of 2019 when the pandemic began. What would you say are the biggest

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: lessons you've learned in a new leadership position navigating the waters of COVID-19?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Very interesting question. I think one of the biggest ones is that you have to prepare for

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: the unexpected, that you should never get comfortable with where you're at

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and be willing and ready to adapt to the change and very quickly. COVID literally and figuratively

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: pulled the rug from all of our feet. And for us at Ushahidi, we had to adapt very fast.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: We made decisions to, you know, we made a decision to waive our platform fees,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: which as risky as it was, ended up paying off in different ways because we've seen a huge surge in use of our platform by vulnerable communities during this time.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And that's also led to discoveries on need to provide more support than just providing the software in itself and guidance, which led us to pilot a web monetization feature with support

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: from Grant for the Web to inject small amounts of money to our users directly from within the

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Ushahidi instances. We've also introduced USSD as a data source to make it easier and cheaper

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: to report into the Ushahidi platform. And as time has gone by, you know, with everything like the, you know, we've seen the Myanmar

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: coup, all the end sales protests in Nigeria, things like Black Lives Matter.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: There's also a need, you know, overwhelming need to also provide secure ways of being

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: able to share information.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And so those are also some of the other things that we're thinking about

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: in terms of our product strategy,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: which wouldn't have happened

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: if we didn't see this surge of use of the platform.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: So that would be one.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: I think the second lesson is that

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: physical interaction is underrated,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: severely underrated.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Yes, we've been put in a situation

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: that has forced us to maintain distance

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and technology has made it easier for us to adapt to that current situation

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: still it's also shown us how difficult it can be to form connections in a virtual setting and also

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: shown how meaningful those connections are in achieving our goals. For example, for me, fundraising, trying to do that in a virtual

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: setting, we're not being able to meet people has been a bit, you know, fairly difficult.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: But at the same time, it's not to say that we can't do it or haven't been doing it. I mean,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: we've had to go ahead and do it. It just means that I've had to put in a lot more effort to

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: form those bonds, while not being able to physically interact with people.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: And moving on to some questions about open source, I'm interested to know what you see as the biggest opportunities for the open source community in Kenya and globally in the near term and the long term?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: I mean, in the near term, the one thing that comes to mind is vaccine inequity.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: That's one of the biggest challenges that we're facing right now. For us in Kenya, there's still substantial information gaps regarding where to access the vaccines. Now, thinking into the long term, COVID may have

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: introduced barriers for physical interaction geographically, but it's also opened our eyes

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: to the possibility of cross-border interaction via the internet, with more remote work opportunities

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: available, organizations worldwide are seeking talent at a global scale, which means you can

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: live in Kenya, but work for a company that has its roots somewhere else, somewhere completely different on another continent. So I think that

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: open source communities should latch onto this opportunity to expand their reach into unexplored

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: regions or markets, because there's so much more knowledge to be shared across different cultures,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: skill sets, etc. And you've been working in the open source community now for many years how

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: were you first introduced to open source and what tips do you have for folks who are curious about

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: working in open source but don't know where to start yeah another interesting question so

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: um it was probably my undergrad studies um both in the classroom, rather the classroom was the first instance.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: You know, I mean, it was part of the part of the curriculum, just understanding what open source is.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: But then my exposure to actually being involved in it was actually during my time volunteering with Ushahidi.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: That started around 2010 when I volunteered with them for the constitutional referendum project and I was hooked from then.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: In terms of tips for people who are curious and don't know where to start, I think one of the first ones is recognizing that you don't have to be a coder to participate in open source projects.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: There's plenty of other parts of the projects that need help. Could be documentation, it could be translation, so many more. You just need to

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: identify the skill set that you would like to share or the area of growth that you want to

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: explore. Because most of the time, yes, there's something that you're able to give, but then

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: there's also an element of these things that you want to learn. Just be very clear and identify

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: what that is. Second thing would be start small

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and make progress with time.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: You'll need to familiarize yourself

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: with how open source generally works

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and how different communities work as well

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: because no open source community is the same.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Each one of them have their own intricacies

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and uniqueness.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: So you'll need to be able to understand

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: what those differences are,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: what the similarities are,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: before you can then move on to more complex projects.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: On the third one,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and probably one of the most important ones,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: immerse yourself in the community of the project

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: that you're getting involved in.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Attend those meetups,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: jump onto the Slack channels,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: the forums, the mailing list,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and the discussions.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Just really put yourself in there and

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: don't be afraid to ask for help when you need it awesome and it's incredible to see you know you

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: started as a volunteer at ushahidi and and now today you're um executive director that's a

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: testament to the work that you've contributed to the organization and the wider open source communities?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: It's, it's, it's, it's, I never saw that happening. But it definitely is when I sit down and reflect

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: about my journey into the organization. It's, it's definitely one for the books.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: And switching gears slightly, over the years, you've spoken very passionately about closing the gender gap

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: in tech across Africa during your time in the sector what changes have you observed

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: and what do you hope to see in the future you can't deny that there's been so much more you

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: know there's been a lot of progress on this front not just in Africa but globally there's an

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: exponential growth in the number of training

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and mentorship programs targeting women in tech

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: or other marginalized groups.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: And we seem to be covering the technical skill development gap well.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: However, in my opinion, there's still a challenge

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: when it comes to the retention of this tech talent,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: especially for women um and growth into

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: leadership opportunities there's still a lot more work that needs to be done to create conducive

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: environments that are welcoming and inviting and i'd like to see more attention and work done on

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: this digging a bit deeper in there what are some of the things that could be done to improve retention for women and other marginalized groups?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: Well, this is something that actually kind of really crosses.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: It's part of the same problem that we experience even in open source communities.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And it really just revolves around conduct, you know, creating codes of conduct.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Like what are the kinds of behaviors that we accept?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Which ones do we not accept?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Because we know there's a lot around harassment against women and marginalized groups.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: There's a lack of pay equity as well.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: You know, when it comes to work-life balance, you know, what types of policies are being put in place to also make it very clear that the environments

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: that we're working in are inviting and welcoming

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: to diverse and, you know, diverse thoughts

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: and diverse skill sets.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: So those would be my three areas,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: looking at harassment and how to, you know,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: basically how to work around that

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: to pay equity and just being more open to diversity, you know, paying more attention

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: to diversity and inclusion. I don't know about you, but I can't wait for Angela's keynote at

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: summit. Folks, make sure you're registered so you don't miss it. Next up on our world tour,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: we head to Bangalore, India where you'll

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: be hearing from Achal Prabhala. Achal is a Shuttleworth Fellow and Coordinator of Access

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: IBSA, a project set up to expand access and speed up the discovery of new drugs in India, Brazil

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: and South Africa. I'm Achal Prabhala and I coordinate the AccessIPSA project which campaigns for access

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: to medicines in India, Brazil and South Africa. I've been working as an activist for access to

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: medicines now coming on 20 years. In between, for a brief while, I also worked on access to knowledge

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: and concentrated more on copyright and the kind of work that Creative

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: Commons is more closely aligned with. But for the large part, I've worked on access to medicines,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: especially for life-threatening conditions like HIV and AIDS, hepatitis C, cancers, cystic fibrosis.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: And in the last two years, in the last year and a half since the pandemic came upon us, I've worked non-stop,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: almost continuously, on access to vaccines. That's an incredible journey and important work,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: and I'm keen to expand on how you got started a little later in the conversation, but I really

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: want to dive into the Access IBSA project. And so the project was founded on a vision of reforming the intellectual

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: property framework in medicine in order to, you know, increase innovation and save more lives.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: And you've been fighting for vaccine equity long before the COVID-19 pandemic, although I'm sure that has, you know, multiplied by, you know, infinity for the past two years.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: Since the start of 2020, late 2019, what do you think are the biggest changes you've observed on

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: this front in terms of, you know, the interest in the vaccine itself and vaccine equity,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: both in positive ways and ways that folks should be paying attention to?

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: The simplest way I can describe what changed when the pandemic began, and especially after

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: vaccines were developed, is that I've been working on this for so long only, and I feel that

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: my own parents, who love me, live very close by, five minutes away, didn't fully understand what I did until the pandemic came about.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: Meaning, I think that the issues I worked with at one level were very simple,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: getting people access to the life-saving medicines they needed.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: That's very simple and understandable.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: But the how of it and the problems on pharmaceutical monopolies associated with it were very difficult, I think, for people to fully grasp.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: They were shrouded in this technical dialogue of trade law and intellectual property and economics.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: And it was just something very difficult for people to wrap their heads around.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: And it was also happening with different diseases around the world. And so where I saw connections and where I had actually worked on several of these campaigns, no one else saw those connections. hepatitis C medicines in Brazil in 2013 has anything to do with the debilitating lack of

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: affordability of HIV medicines in Southern Africa in 2000. But they were all coming from the same

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: root problem. And I think actually one of the failures of work like mine and other activists

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: has been not to be able to communicate that popularly. Tragically, what changed in the

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: pandemic is that everyone around the world had a sort of universal investment in getting a vaccine

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: and understanding why they weren't getting a vaccine if they lived in countries like mine or

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: worse. And that meant, for better or worse, that people suddenly began to take a very personal interest in these arcane issues. And

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: what I've seen over the last one and a half years that I've been working on this is that I have to

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: explain less and less. It used to be even at the start of the pandemic, when we started looking at

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: vaccine monopolies prior to there being even vaccines in the world, trying to forestall what we saw as an

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: inevitable problem, I'd have to start right at the beginning. I'd have to go back to South Africa in

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: 1999, my own work in that country in 2002, to build that story up from scratch in order to be able to

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: put what was happening in the present day in context. And

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: I find that I have to do that less and less, almost to the extent now that the phrase vaccine

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: apartheid or the phrase vaccine inequity is universally understood. People get it instantly.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: People get the implications of it. And I think that's really positive,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: though it hasn't actually resulted in any gains, particularly in the pandemic. I think that

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: perhaps for the very first time in the last six months, the pharmaceutical industry is on the

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: back foot and has to constantly justify the monopoly positions it's taken on these

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: vaccines, which it's refusing to budge on, but still has to justify them, which is, I think,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: a huge change from what it used to be like before. And you touched on these monopolies. I recently

So, you know, we can see that the interest in vaccines has,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: you know, sprouted tremendously during the pandemic and, you know, both to a positive

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: effect and now in terms of monopolies, we're seeing some of that negative capitalist interest coming in there. I wonder what the solutions are.

speakers.text: One of the hardest things to navigate through this pandemic,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: for me personally, has been the personal effect of the pandemic.

speakers.text: I lived through India in April and May.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03
speakers.text: I've lived through India right through the last 18 months

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_03

speakers.text: I can't actually travel anywhere. But I'm happy to be here with my family. But April and May and

speakers.text: And having lived through that, it struck me, I think everybody grieves,

speakers.text: and things became better. A close friend of mine, someone who I have worked with and known for
